0.0: [Mishnah]  ALL [PERSONS] ARE FIT TO EVALUATE OR TO BE MADE THE SUBJECTS OF VALUATION, ARE FIT TO VOW [ANOTHER'S WORTH] OR HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED: — PRIESTS, LEVITES AND [ORDINARY] ISRAELITES, WOMEN AND SLAVES.
0.1: PERSONS OF UNKNOWN SEX AND HERMAPHRODITES ARE FIT TO VOW [ANOTHER'S WORTH], OR TO HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED, AND ARE FIT TO EVALUATE, BUT THEY ARE NOT FIT TO BE MADE THE SUBJECTS OF VALUATION, FOR THE SUBJECT OF VALUATION MAY BE ONLY A PERSON DEFINITELY EITHER MALE OR FEMALE.
0.2: A DEAF-MUTE, AN IMBECILE, OR A MINOR ARE FIT TO HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED OR BE MADE THE SUBJECT OF VALUATION, BUT THEY ARE NOT FIT TO MAKE EITHER A VOW [OF ANOTHER'S WORTH] OR TO EVALUATE, BECAUSE THEY HAVE NO MIND.
0.3: [Gemarah]  What does ALL [PERSONS] ARE FIT TO EVALUATE mean to include?
0.4: — It is meant to include one close to manhood who must be examined.
0.5: What does [ALL7 ARE] FIT TO BE MADE THE SUBJECTS OF VALUATION mean to include? —
0.6: It is meant to include a person disfigured, or one afflicted with boils.
0.7: For one might have assumed that since Scripture says:
0.8: A vow according to thy valuation, that only such persons as are fit to be made the subjects of a vow [as regards their worth], are fit to be made subjects of a valuation, and that persons who are unfit to be made subjects of a vow [as regards their worth], are also unfit to be made subjects of a valuation, hence Scripture informs us: of persons. i.e.,
0.10: What does [ALL PERSONS] ARE FIT TO VOW mean to include? —
0.11: [The phrase ALL] is needed only for [the clause]
0.12: ‘are fit to have their worth vowed’
0.13: — What is to be included [in the phrase ALL] ARE FIT TO HAVE THEIR WORTH VOWED? Is it to include persons of unknown sex or hermaphrodites — but they are expressly stated [in our Mishnah]! Again is it to include a deaf-mute, an imbecile and a minor — they too are expressly stated! And if it is to include a person below the age of one month — that too is expressly mentioned! And again if it is to include an idolater — he too is expressly mentioned!
0.14: — In reality it is meant to include a person below the age of one month; and the Mishnah states it [by implication] and later on expressly mentions it.
0.15: What does ‘All persons are obliged to lay on hands’ mean to include?
0.16: — It is meant to include the heir, and this against the view of R. Judah.
0.17: What does ‘All persons can effect a substitute’ mean to include? —
0.18: That, too, means to include the heir, in contrast to the view of R. Judah.
0.20: An heir must lay on hands, an heir can effect a substitute.
0.22: An heir does not lay on hands, and an heir cannot effect a substitute.
0.23: What is the reason of R. Judah's view?
0.24: — [Scripture says:] His offering,(Leviticus 1:3) i.e., but not his father's offering.
0.25: And he infers the rule concerning the commencement of the dedication of the animal from the rule governing its end.
0.26: Just as at the end of the dedication the heir does not lay on hands, thus also at the beginning he cannot effect a substitute.
0.28: — [Scripture says redundantly:] And if he shall at all change — that included the heir.(Leviticus 27:10)
0.29: And we infer the rule concerning the end of the dedication from the rule governing the commencement of the dedication.
0.30: Just as at the beginning of the dedication the heir has power to effect a substitute, so at the end is he obliged to lay his hands on the animal's head.
0.31: But what do the Rabbis do with
0.33: ‘his offering’, but not the offering of an idolater; ‘his offering’, but not the offering of his neighbour; ‘his offering. i.e., to include all who have a share in the ownership of a sacrifice in the duty to lay on hands.
0.34: And R. Judah? — He does not hold that all who have a share in the ownership share the obligation of laying hands thereon;
0.35: or, indeed, if he should hold so
